title: What We Know About the Police Shooting of Daunte Wright in Minneapolis Suburb
sub_head: Officer kills 20-year-old Black man during traffic stop; police official says officer had intended to use her Taser
body:
The Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension identified Kim Potter, a 26-year veteran of the Brooklyn Center, Minn., police force, as the officer who police said accidentally shot and killed Daunte Wright on Sunday after discharging her gun instead of her Taser. The shooting happened during a traffic stop.
Ms. Potter said in a letter to city officials on Tuesday that she believed it was in the best interest of the community and the police department to resign. She was taken into custody Wednesday and charged with second-degree manslaughter
Police Chief Tim Gannon also resigned Tuesday, the day after the city manager was fired by Brooklyn Center Mayor Mike Elliott. Ms.
In Minnesota, second-degree manslaughter means the defendant allegedly took an unreasonable risk that resulted in someone’s death. It has been used to prosecute hunting accidents. It carries a maximum sentence of 10 years and a fine of $20,000.
Mr. Wright was a 20-year-old Black man. An undated handout photo provided by Ben Crump Law shows Daunte Wright and his son Daunte Jr., at his first birthday party. During a rally for her son, Katie Wright, Mr. Wright’s mother, said he had “a smile that was angelic” and “lit up the room.”
